steering_file.title: steering_script
steering_file.description: object describes how to decode all raw data into object containing all hepdata information.

table_name.description: name of the table (simple names only!)

should_be_processed.description: flag whether table should be processed (checked and information used) or just skipped

table_title.description: title of the table; put into HEPData

table_location.description: Location of the table on the paper website

table_keywords.description: keywords attributed specifically to the table

cuts_to_apply.description: cut on all visible variables and their errors (numpy based)

variables.description: collections of all variables stored in the table

comment.description: any comment user might want to put

table_signal.description: specify if only one signal populates all entries in the table

table_grid.description: specify if only one grid populates all entries in the table

table_region.description: specify if only one (signal?) region populates all entries in the table

is_visible.description: specify whether variable is visible in the final table and whether additional checks are made on it

fancy_name.description: fancy name (can contain all beautification characters/latex commands)

in_files.description: list of input files defining the variable

astype.description: specify how should the variable be treated

transformations.description: list of transformations run with pythons' eval

decode.description: command to get the data from input file. The syntax depends on the input file type!

table_loc_decode.description: (used only if the input file is .tex) command to get the interesting table from latex source (using TexSoup, and 'latex' is the name of the objetc containing loaded tex file)

replace_dict.description: (used only if the input file is .tex) dictionary containing words and their replacement to be used after latex table has been loaded but before decode step.

delimiter.description: (usef for csv files only), specify which delimiter is used between columns in the file

file_type.description: force type of the file (do not guess it from the text name)
